metadata.title: Effect of Zr on catalytic performance of unsupported Ni(Zr)Mo and Ni(Zr)W sulfide catalysts for quinoline hydrodenitrogenation

Scheme 1 Scheme 2 The whole reaction network of quinoline hydrodenitrogenation. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 A simplified reaction network of quinoline hydrodenitrogenation (the thick arrows represent the main reaction pathways). Scheme 3 Fig. 1 XRD patterns of Ni(Zr)-LDHs (a) and Ni(Zr) oxides (b). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TPR profiles of NiO and NiZr oxide. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the oxidic precursors of Ni(Zr)MoS (a) and Ni(Zr)WS (b) catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TPR profiles of the oxidic precursors of Ni(Zr)MoS (a) and Ni(Zr)WS (b) catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of Ni(Zr)MoS (a) and Ni(Zr)WS (b) catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TEM images, distributions and averages of stacking number (Nav) and slab length (Lav) of MoS2/WS2 crystallites of four sulfided catalysts: NM (a, e, i), NZM-3 (b, f, j), NW (c, g, k) and NZW-3 (d, h, l). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 HDN activities (a) and selectivities (b, c, d) of Ni(Zr)MoS catalysts: NM (□), NZM-1 (○), NZM-2 (△), NZM-3 (◇), NZM-4 (+), NZM-5 (×). Reactions conditions: T = 300 °C, P(H2) = 3.5 MPa and H2/oil ratio = 600 V/V. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 HDN activities (a) and selectivities (b, c, d) of Ni(Zr)WS catalysts: NW (□), NZW-1 (○), NZW-2 (△), NZW-3 (◇), NZW-4 (+), NZW-5 (×). Reactions conditions: T = 300 °C, P(H2) = 3.5 MPa and H2/oil ratio = 600 V/V. Fig. 8 Table 1 The elemental composition of the oxidic precursors of Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts. Table 1 Cat. Table 3 Catalyst kHDN (h−1) Catalyst kHDN (h−1) NM 2.42 NW 5.68 NZM-1 5.30 NZW-1 12.0 NZM-2 7.85 NZW-2 17.4 NZM-3 9.18 NZW-3 23.0 NZM-4 8.35 NZW-4 18.3 NZM-5 7.28 NZW-5 13.3 Effect of Zr on catalytic performance of unsupported Ni(Zr)Mo and Ni(Zr)W sulfide catalysts for quinoline hydrodenitrogenation Xinyi Liu a b Cen Zhang a b Tiefeng Liu a Zongxuan Jiang a * Can Li a * a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract To increase the dispersion of active species and full utilization of active metals are of great importance for hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) performance of unsupported hydrotreating catalysts. Herein, a series of unsupported Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts were prepared from Ni(Zr) layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors. The Zr species remarkably promote the dispersion and reducibility of NiMo and NiW composite species. Also, the total HDN rate constants are increased from 2.42 h−1 to 9.18 h−1 for Ni(Zr)MoS and from 5.68 h−1 to 23.0 h−1 for Ni(Zr)WS, and exhibit a maximum at a Zr/Ni atomic ratio of about 0.04. The HDN selectivities indicate that the Zr species increase the number of superficial active sites without affecting their structure. The present work shows that the crystallinity of LDH precursors is crucial to the structure of unsupported sulfide catalysts, and a suitable amount of Zr could be a dispersive promoter to increase the HDN activity. Keywords Unsupported catalyst Hydrodenitrogenation Hydrotreating 1 Introduction Hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) is necessary for refinery processes because of the poisoning effect of basic N-containing compounds in fossil fuel on acidic active sites over zeolite catalysts. Also, N-containing compounds exhibit a strong inhibiting effect on hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction [1,2], which is detrimental to ultra-deep HDS. Similar to HDS catalysts, NiMoS/Al2O3, NiWS/Al2O3 or NiMoWS/Al2O3 catalysts are commonly used for HDN in industry [3–5]. Since the hydrogenation steps before hydrogenolysis are indispensable for aromatic heterocyclic N-containing compounds and CN bond is usually much stronger than CS bond, ultra-deep HDN is more challenging than ultra-deep HDS. Around 2001, unsupported catalysts based on NEBULA technology were reported to show more superior HDS and HDN activities than conventional alumina supported hydrotreating catalysts [6,7]. Moreover, unsupported catalysts with different metallic composition were studied and the HDS performances of them were improved by introducing other appropriate metal components [8–12]. Unsupported catalysts have great potential for industrial applications due to their excellent hydrotreating performance, however, they are still limited by the high metal contents and the resulting high costs. Thus, how to increase the dispersion and utilization of active metals is one of the key issues for improving the hydrotreating activities of unsupported catalysts. Layered double hydroxide (LDH) is consisted of layers composed of divalent metal cations octahedrally coordinated by hydroxyl groups. While a part of original metal cations is substituted, the layers will be positively charged and exchangeable negatively charged interlayer anions (such as CO3 2−, NO3 − et al) will appear to balance the charges. In our previous work, using NiAl-LDH [8], NiZn-LDH [9] and NiZnAl-LDH [10] as structural templates followed by introducing Mo/W via ion-exchange was demonstrated to be a practical method to prepare unsupported multi-metallic sulfide catalysts, and the as-prepared catalysts showed much higher catalytic activity for HDS of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene compared with alumina supported hydrotreating catalysts. For single metallic Ni-LDH, although there is no stoichiometric interlayer anion, the layered structure still allows a certain amount of active metal species to insert and disperses them. Thus, unsupported NiMoWS catalysts using Ni-LDH as a precursor also exhibited outstanding HDS activity [13]. However, the HDN performance of such catalysts remains unclear. Hence, in the present work, unsupported Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts with different Zr amounts were prepared, characterized and evaluated for HDN of quinoline, and the influence of Zr on the HDN performance is discussed in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. Unsupported Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts were prepared according to the procedure reported in the previous work [13]. Firstly, Ni-LDH precursor was prepared by a precipitation method. Typically, 40 mmol nickel acetate tetrahydrate was dissolved in deionized water to form a homogeneous solution, and this solution was added into a three port flask and kept at 100 °C. Afterwards, a solution of Na2CO3 (0.1 M) was added dropwise under vigorous stirring to adjust the pH value to 10 and a green precipitate of Ni-LDH was formed. For the preparation of NiZr-LDH precursors, the Zr content was introduced by a further deposition: a certain amount of zirconium acetate solution was then added to the green suspension, and a small amount of Na2CO3 solution was also added to keep the pH value constant. After keeping at 100 °C for 1 h, the precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water, and the LDH precursors were denoted as N-LDH or NZ-LDH-x. For the preparation of oxidic Ni(Zr)Mo catalysts, ammonium heptamolybdate containing 20 mmol Mo was dissolved in 40 mL deionized water in a flask, followed by adding Ni(Zr)-LDH precursors under vigorous stirring to form a suspension. Then, the suspension was kept at 90 °C until water was evaporated completely, and the oxidic catalysts were obtained after drying overnight and calcination at 380 °C for 4 h. For the preparation of oxidic Ni(Zr)W catalysts, only a substitution of ammonium heptamolybdate by ammonium metatungstate containing 20 mmol W was needed. Here, the Ni(Zr)Mo catalysts were denoted as NM or NZM-x and the Ni(Zr)W catalysts were denoted as NW or NZW-x. Besides, all Ni(Zr)-LDH precursors were calcined to prepare Ni(Zr) oxides denoted as N-O or NZ-O-x. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray fluorescence (XRF) elemental analysis was performed on a Magix-2424 XRF spectrometer to determine the elemental compositions. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a PANalytical Empyrean powder diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Each XRD pattern was collected from 10° to 80° at a speed of 5°/min. N2-physisorption was performed at 77 K on a Quantachrome instrument. The surface area was calculated using the multi-point Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method by assuming the section area of nitrogen molecule is 0.162 nm2. The total pore volume was calculated by the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at P/P0 = 0.98. Before the test, each sample was outgassed in a vacuum (about 10−4 Torr) at 300 °C for 6 h. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected on a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin (FEI Company) instrument at an acceleration voltage of 300 kV. The distributions and averages of the stacking number and slab length of MoS2/WS2 crystallites were calculated, and the equations for calculating the average stacking number (Nav) and slab length (Lav) were listed in the supporting information. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles were collected on a TPR instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before the test, each sample was preheated in Ar at 130 °C for 1 h. Then, the sample was heated to 900 °C (10 °C/min) in 5 vol.% H2/Ar with a flow rate of 50 mL/min. 2.3 Catalyst performance evaluation The HDN performance evaluation was performed on a high-pressure fixed-bed continuous flow microreactor using a solution of quinoline in decalin with a nitrogen contents of 500 ppmw as feed. Prior to the HDN evaluation, the shaped oxidic catalyst was loaded and in-situ sulfided at 400 °C in 10 vol.% H2S/H2 for 2.5 h. Subsequently, the HDN reaction was carried out at 300 °C, a H2 pressure of 3.5 MPa, a liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of 4.5−36 h−1 and a H2/oil ratio of 600 V/V. After a stabilization period of 5 h, the product was collected and analyzed. The total nitrogen amount was determined on an Antek azotometer and the components were analyzed on an Agilent 6890 N gas chromatograph with a DB-FFAP capillary column (30 m × 0.320 mm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and reducibility of Ni(Zr)-LDHs and Ni(Zr) oxides Fig. 1 a shows the XRD patterns of Ni(Zr)-LDH precursors, and the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 33.1°, 38.5°, 52.1°, 59.1°, 62.8° are attributed to β-Ni(OH)2 (JPCDS 14−0017), which has a typical brucite-like layered structure. The two peaks at 2θ = 16.1° and 20.3° are different from the standard (001) peak at 2θ = 19.2°, implying two interlayer spacings. Fig. 1b shows the XRD patterns of Ni(Zr) oxides, and the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 43.3°, 62.9°, 75.4°, 79.4° are attributed to bunsenite (JPCDS 47−1049). For either Ni(Zr)-LDHs or Ni(Zr) oxides, all diffraction peaks associated with Ni species are weakened and broadened dramatically with increasing the Zr content, indicating that the introduction of Zr remarkably decreases the crystallinity of β-Ni(OH)2 (Ni-LDH) and such effect is retained after calcination. Also, the two (001) peaks of Ni-LDH merge gradually with increasing the Zr content, implying the convergence of interlayer spacings. Besides, the absence of crystalline Zr species suggests that they are amorphous and highly dispersed on Ni-LDH crystallites. The reducibilities of NiO and NiZr composite oxide are compared as shown in Fig. 2 . Since bulk ZrO2 can hardly be reduced by H2 [14–17], the consumption of H2 is attributed to the reduction of NiO. The reduction peak of pure NiO is located at 389 °C. With increasing the Zr content, this peak is weakened and a new reduction peak at 464 °C is increased gradually. The TPR results indicate that Zr species have interaction with NiO [15], probably through substituting the hydroxyl groups of Ni-LDH, and such interaction hinders the reduction of NiO. Considering that the Zr species are deposited after the precipitation of Ni-LDH, we suggest that they are predominantly located on the surface of Ni-LDH particles. The superficial Zr species inhibit the aggregation and growth of Ni-LDH crystallites, and such effect is retained after calcination (Scheme 1 ). 3.2 Structure and reducibility of the oxidic precursors of Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts The elemental compositions of oxidic Ni(Zr)Mo and Ni(Zr)W catalysts are listed in Table 1 . Either Mo/Ni or W/Ni atomic ratio in each oxidic catalyst is essentially consistent with the raw materials. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of oxidic Ni(Zr)Mo and Ni(Zr)W catalysts. The oxidic precursors of NiMoS and NiWS catalysts (NM and NW) exhibit three peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 43.3° and 62.9° associated with crystalline phase of NiO derived from residual Ni-LDH. Moreover, the peaks of NiO phase disappear with the introduction of Zr, indicating that the decrease in the crystallinity of Ni-LDH is conducive to the dispersion of Ni species in the oxidic catalysts. For oxidic Ni(Zr)Mo catalysts (Fig. 3a), both α-NiMoO4 (JPCDS 33−0948) and β-NiMoO4 (JPCDS 45−0142) are observed. In addition, there is a transformation form α phase into β phase with the introduction of Zr. Renzo et al. [18] and Mazzocchia et al. [19] reported that the excessive Ni content helps to stabilize β-NiMoO4 phase by inserting Ni into the NiMoO4 lattice. Thus, the transformation of NiMoO4 phase could be attributed to the increasing dispersion of NiO, which promotes the contact between Ni species and NiMoO4. In the case of oxidic Ni(Zr)W catalysts (Fig. 3b), the peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 41.0°, 53.7°, 64.2° are attributed to a crystalline phase of (NH4)aNibWcOx reported by Soled [20]. Further, the dispersive promoting effect of Zr on the oxidic catalysts is also proved by N2-physisorption (Table 2 ): it makes the surface area larger (from 164 m2/g to 180 m2/g for oxidic Ni(Zr)Mo catalysts and from 143 m2/g to 170 m2/g for oxidic Ni(Zr)W catalysts) and the pore volume smaller (from 0.33 cm3/g to 0.21 cm3/g for oxidic Ni(Zr)Mo catalysts and from 0.29 cm3/g to 0.19 cm3/g m2/g for oxidic Ni(Zr)W catalysts). Besides, each oxidic catalyst exhibits a type IV of isotherm with H2-type of hysteresis (Fig. S1), which is the characteristic of mesoporous material with nonuniform pore structure according to the IUPAC classification. Fig. 4 exhibits the TPR profiles of oxidic Ni(Zr)Mo and Ni(Zr)W catalysts. For oxidic Ni(Zr)Mo catalysts (Fig. 4a), NM shows a major peak at 580 °C, a weak peak at about 529 ℃ which overlaps with the most intense peak at 580 ℃ and a broad weak peak from 700 °C to 900 °C. The peaks below 700 °C could be attributed to the simultaneous reduction of Ni2+ and polymeric octahedral (Oh) Mo6+ species while the weak peak at high temperature could be corresponding to the reduction of isolated tetrahedral (Td) Mo6+ species [21,22]. With the introduction of Zr, the peak at above 700 °C is disappeared, the peak at 580 °C is weakened and the peak at 529 ℃ is increased. These results demonstrate that the Zr species promote the transformation of Td Mo6+ species to Oh Mo6+ species and increase the reducibility of Oh Mo6+ species. In the case of oxidic Ni(Zr)W catalysts, NW shows two peaks at 527 °C and 690 °C. The first peak below 600 °C could be assigned to the simultaneous reduction of Ni2+ and polymeric octahedral (Oh) W6+ species while the second peak over 650 °C could be attributed to the reduction of dimeric tetrahedral (Td) W6+ species [23,24]. With the introduction of Zr, the first peak is shifted to 472 °C. Moreover, the peak at 690 °C is weakened gradually and a new peak corresponding to the reduction of Oh W6+ species [23] is observed at 585 °C. These results show that the effect of Zr on W species is quite similar to that on Mo species, that is, it promotes the transformation of Td W6+ species to Oh W6+ species and increase the reducibility of Oh W6+ species. Therefore, it could be concluded that the introduction of Zr promotes the reducibility of NiMo and NiW species, which is conducive to the activation of the oxidic catalysts. 3.3 Structure of unsupported Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts The crystalline structures of unsupported Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . Here, MoS2 (JPCDS 37−1492) and WS2 (JPCDS 08−0237) phase with very similar patterns are observed. Besides, the peaks at 2θ = 21.8°, 31.1°, 37.8°, 38.3°, 44.3°, 49.7°, 50.1° and 55.2° are corresponding to Ni3S2 phase (JPCDS 44−1418). For both Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts, the peaks associated with Ni3S2 are weakened with the introduction of Zr, implying a decrease in crystalline nickel sulfide phase. Since nickel sulfide phase also acts as a support, the exposure of composite NiMo or NiW species on surface of particles is probably promoted by the introduction of Zr. Fig. 6 a-d shows the morphologies of Ni(Zr)MoS (NM and NZM-3) and Ni(Zr)WS (NW and NZW-3) catalysts. Each sulfided catalyst is composed of nickel sulfide particles with a size of 10−20 nm and MoS2 or WS2 phase at the striate regions. In addition, for either Ni(Zr)MoS or Ni(Zr)WS catalysts, it is observed that the distributions of stacking number (Fig. 6e-h) and slab length (Fig. 6i-l) of MoS2 or WS2 are not distinctly influenced by Zr species: the average stacking number (Nav: from 2.5 to 2.5 for Ni(Zr)MoS and from 2.5 to 2.5 for Ni(Zr)WS) and slab length (Lav: from 6.9 nm to 7.0 nm for Ni(Zr)MoS and from 6.5 nm to 6.5 nm for Ni(Zr)WS) are almost the same. These results indicate that the introduction of Zr scarcely influences the morphologies of MoS2 and WS2 crystallites. 3.4 Catalytic performances and kinetics of quinoline HDN A whole reaction network of quinoline HDN is shown in Scheme 2 [3–5,25,26]. Firstly, the heterocyclic ring of quinoline (Q) is hydrogenated rapidly to form 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline (THQ-1) and an equilibrium between them is established [27–29]. Thus, Q and THQ-1 are lumped together as the original reactant to calculate the conversion (Conv., including all conversion mentioned without further description): Conv . = 1 − C Q p + C THQ − 1 p C Q f × 100 % where Cf Q, Cp Q and Cp THQ-1 are the concentrations of quinoline (Q) in feed, Q in product and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline (THQ-1) in product, respectively. Also, the carbocyclic ring of Q can be hydrogenated to form 5,6,7,8-tetrahydroquinoline (THQ-5). Both THQ-1 and THQ-5 can be further hydrogenated to form decahydroquinoline (DHQ). Then, the first hydrogenolysis step involving CN bond cleavage takes place on THQ-1 and DHQ to form propylaniline (OPA) and propylcyclohexylamine (PCHA), respectively. Afterwards, the nitrogen atom of PCHA is removed via a Hofmann elimination to form propylcyclohexene (PCHE), and propylbenzene (PB) could be formed via a direct denitrogenation (DDN) of OPA. Finally, propylcyclohexane (PCH) is formed via hydrogenation of PCHE. Besides, PCHE could be formed via hydrogenation of PB. The selectivities (Sel.) are calculated by the equation as follows: Sel . i = C i p ∑ i C i p × 100 % = C i p C Q f − C Q p − C THQ-1 p × 100 % = C i p C Q f × Conv . × 100 % where Sel.i and Cp i are the selectivity and concentration of compound i in product, respectively. For quinoline HDN reaction in this work, i could be THQ-5, DHQ, OPA, PB, PCH or entire hydrocarbons (HC). In addition, the total HDN rate constants (kHDN) could also be calculated by assuming a pseudo-first-order reaction: k HDN = − LHSV × ln N p N f where LHSV is the liquid hourly space velocity and Np and Nf are the total N content in product and feed, respectively. Fig. 7 a and Fig. 8 a exhibit the HDN activities of Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts. It is observed that each Ni(Zr)WS catalyst shows a higher HDN activity than Ni(Zr)MoS catalyst with a same Zr/Ni atomic ratio. Moreover, as shown in Table 3 , the HDN activities of Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts are increased by the introduction of Zr (from 2.42 h−1 to 9.18 h−1 for Ni(Zr)MoS and from 5.68 h−1 to 23.0 h−1 for Ni(Zr)WS), and both of them exhibit a maximum at a Zr/Ni atomic ratio of about 0.04. These results imply that the promoting effect of Zr on the HDN activity could be attributed to the influence of Zr on LDH precursors. Figs. 7b-c and 8 b-c exhibit the selectivities of N-containing intermediates and entire hydrocarbons (including PCHE, PCH and PB) as a function of conversion. For all catalysts, the selectivity of THQ-5 is quite low because THQ-5 has a slow formation rate and a fast consumption rate [30]. Therefore, DHQ should be predominantly formed via the hydrogenation of THQ-1. Besides, since the adsorption of aniline is much weaker than that of DHQ [31] and C−N(sp2) bond is stronger than CN(sp3) bond, the hydrogenolysis of THQ-1 to form OPA is limited. Hence, the first hydrogenolysis step predominantly takes place on DHQ to form PCHA, and the selectivity of OPA keeps at a rather low level. Here, PCHA is not detected owing to its high reactivity that the N atom is removed rapidly via a Hofmann elimination to form PCHE. Afterwards, PCHE can be further hydrogenated to form PCH. Additionally, considering the conjugation between the nitrogen atom and the benzene ring, the hydrogenolysis of OPA to PB is also a slow step. Based on the above, the whole reaction network of quinoline HDN could be simplified (Scheme 3 ): (Q + THQ-1) → DHQ → [PCHA] → PCHE → PCH. From Figs. 7b-d and 8 b-d, each selectivity of THQ-5, DHQ, OPA or entire hydrocarbons as a function of conversion shows the same trend for all Ni(Zr)MoS or Ni(Zr)WS catalysts, whereas the selectivities of PB and PCH are increased slightly with the introduction of Zr. 3.5 Effect of Zr on Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts and catalytic performances for quinoline HDN First of all, the introduction of Zr brings Ni-LDH precursor smaller crystalline size, and such effect could also be retained after calcination. Considering that Zr is introduced after the precipitation of Ni-LDH, the Zr species are probably located on surface. Thus, the dispersive promoting effect of Zr should be derived from the inhibition on growth and aggregation of Ni-LDH crystallites, and facilitates the reaction of Ni-LDH with molybdate and tungstate. In addition, the Zr species increase the surface area of the oxidic catalysts, which is beneficial to the dispersion of the NiMo and NiW composite species. Further, the introduction of Zr results in a transformation from tetrahedral Mo6+ and W6+ species (harder to be reduced) to octahedral Mo6+ and W6+ species (easier to be reduced), and also decreases the reduction temperature of the latter. Hence, it could be concluded that the textures of LDH precursors could strongly influence the properties of the oxidic catalysts, and the introduction of Zr promotes the dispersion and reducibility of NiMo and NiW composite species. The HDN activities of Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts are increased by the introduction of Zr. In comparison, for THQ-5, DHQ, OPA and hydrocarbons which are converted from N-containing intermediates, the selectivities at the same conversion are scarcely influenced. The hydrotreating active sites are considered to locate at the edge of stacked MoS2 or WS2 layers incorporated with Ni atoms (NiMoS or NiWS active species) [32–34]. Considering that the distributions and averages of stacking number and slab length of MoS2 or WS2 phase do not distinctly change with the introduction of Zr, we thus suggest that the Zr species do not influence the structure of active sites and the increase the number of superficial active sites should be the reason for the increasing HDN activity. On the other hand, the HDN activities exhibit a maximum at a Zr/Ni atomic ratio of about 0.04 for both Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts. Considering the location of Zr species, they could retard the contact between active sites and reactants. As a consequence, the excessive Zr content is detrimental to the HDN activity. Besides, the selectivities of PB and PCH are increased with the introduction of Zr, indicating the hydrogenolysis of OPA and the hydrogenation of PCHE is promoted. Also, the increasing effect on the selectivity of PCH is more pronounced than that of PB, implying that the hydrogenation of PB is promoted as well. Since the adsorption of DHQ on active sites is much stronger than that of other intermediates [31], the adsorption of other species should be critical to their conversion. Hence, we suppose that the introduction of Zr presumably promotes the desorption of DHQ on Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts. 4 Conclusions A series of unsupported Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts with different Zr amounts were prepared from Ni(Zr)-LDH precursors. Since the Zr species facilitate the dispersion and reducibility of the oxidic NiMo and NiW composite species, the activation of active phases and the exposure of active NiMoS and NiWS species on surface of catalyst particles are promoted. The HDN activities of both Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts exhibit a maximum at a Zr/Ni atomic ratio of about 0.04 owing to an increase in the number of superficial active sites. Besides, presumably due to the enhancement of the desorption of DHQ on Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts, the introduction of Zr slightly promotes the conversion of OPA, PCHE and PB, and increases the selectivities of PB and PCH. coredata.dc:description: To increase the dispersion of active species and full utilization of active metals are of great importance for hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) performance of unsupported hydrotreating catalysts. Herein, a series of unsupported Ni(Zr)MoS and Ni(Zr)WS catalysts were prepared from Ni(Zr) layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors. The Zr species remarkably promote the dispersion and reducibility of NiMo and NiW composite species. Also, the total HDN rate constants are increased from 2.42 h−1 to 9.18 h−1 for Ni(Zr)MoS and from 5.68 h−1 to 23.0 h−1 for Ni(Zr)WS, and exhibit a maximum at a Zr/Ni atomic ratio of about 0.04. The HDN selectivities indicate that the Zr species increase the number of superficial active sites without affecting their structure. The present work shows that the crystallinity of LDH precursors is crucial to the structure of unsupported sulfide catalysts, and a suitable amount of Zr could be a dispersive promoter to increase the HDN activity.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of Zr on catalytic performance of unsupported Ni(Zr)Mo and Ni(Zr)W sulfide catalysts for quinoline hydrodenitrogenation
